 Section 127I

Data from Section 127I:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><div class="pagebody"><div id="content"><div class="pagebody"><div id="content"><p><span>        <span>         <strong>          Section 127-I. Power of Settlement Commission to send a case back to the proper officer. -         </strong></span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (1)The Settlement Commission may, if it is of opinion that any person who made an application for settlement under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> has not co-operated with the Settlement Commission in the proceedings before it, send the case back to the proper officer who shall thereupon dispose of the case in accordance with the provisions of this Act as if no application under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> had been made.        </span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (2) For the purpose of sub-section (1), the proper officer shall be entitled to use all the materials and other information produced by the assessee before the Settlement Commission or the results of the inquiry held or evidence recorded by the Settlement Commission in the course of the proceedings before it as if such materials, information, inquiry and evidence had been produced before such proper officer or held or recorded by him in the course of the proceedings before him.        </span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (3) For the purposes of the time limit under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000046/1000002" alt="section 28">section 28</a> and for the purposes of interest under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000048/1000002" alt="section 28AA">section 28AA</a>, in a case referred to in sub-section (1), the period commencing on and from the date of the application to the Settlement Commission under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> and ending with the date of receipt by the officer of customs of the order of the Settlement Commission sending the case back to the officer of customs shall be excluded.        </span></span></p></div></div></div></div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><div class="pagebody"><div id="content"><div class="pagebody"><div id="content"><p><span>        <span>         <strong>          Section 127-I. Power of Settlement Commission to send a case back to the proper officer. -         </strong></span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (1)The Settlement Commission may, if it is of opinion that any person who made an application for settlement under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> has not co-operated with the Settlement Commission in the proceedings before it, send the case back to the proper officer who shall thereupon dispose of the case in accordance with the provisions of this Act as if no application under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> had been made.        </span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (2) For the purpose of sub-section (1), the proper officer shall be entitled to use all the materials and other information produced by the assessee before the Settlement Commission or the results of the inquiry held or evidence recorded by the Settlement Commission in the course of the proceedings before it as if such materials, information, inquiry and evidence had been produced before such proper officer or held or recorded by him in the course of the proceedings before him.        </span></span></p><p><span>        <span>         (3) For the purposes of the time limit under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000046/1000002" alt="section 28">section 28</a> and for the purposes of interest under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000048/1000002" alt="section 28AA">section 28AA</a>, in a case referred to in sub-section (1), the period commencing on and from the date of the application to the Settlement Commission under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000195/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000189/1000002" alt="section 127B">section 127B</a> and ending with the date of receipt by the officer of customs of the order of the Settlement Commission sending the case back to the officer of customs shall be excluded.        </span></span></p></div></div></div></div></span>

      <p lang="en-US">
       <span>
        <span>
         <strong>
          Section 127M. Proceedings before Settlement Commission to be judicial proceedings. -
         </strong>
        </span>
       </span>
      </p>
      <p align="JUSTIFY" lang="en-US">
       <span>
        <span>
         Any proceedings under this Chapter before the Settlement Commission shall be deemed to be a judicial proceeding within the meaning of sections 193 and 228, and for the purposes of section 196, of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860).
        </span>
       </span>
      </p>

    </div>

  <b>
   Section 128.  Appeals to
   <sup>
    1
   </sup>
   [Commissioner
(Appeals)]. -
   <br>
   <br>
  </b>
  (1) Any person aggrieved by any decision or order passed under this Act by
an officer of customs lower in rank than a
  <sup>
   2
  </sup>
  [Principal
Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] may appeal to the
  <sup>
   1
  </sup>
  [Commissioner (Appeals)]
  <sup>
   3
  </sup>
  [within
sixty days] from the date of the communication to him of such decision or
order:
  <div>
   <br>
   <sup>
    4
   </sup>
   [
   <b>
    Provided
   </b>
   that the Commissioner (Appeals) may, if he is
satisfied that the appellant was prevented by sufficient cause from presenting
the appeal within the aforesaid period of sixty days, allow it to be presented
within a further period of thirty days.]
   <br>
   <br>
   <sup>
    5
   </sup>
   [(1A)   The Commissioner (Appeals) may, if
sufficient cause is shown at any stage of hearing of an appeal, grant time,
from time to time, to the parties or any of them and adjourn the hearing of the
appeal for reasons to be recorded in writing:
   <br>
   <br>
  </div>
  <div>
   <b>
    Provided
   </b>
   that no such adjournment shall be granted more than three times to a
party during hearing of the appeal.]
   <br>
   <br>
   (2) Every appeal under this section, shall be in such form and
shall be verified in such manner as may be specified by rules made in this
behalf.
   <br>
   <br>
   <div class="footnotes">
    1. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1995 (22 of 1995), section 50, for "Collector (Appeals)"
(w.e.f. 26.05.1995).
    <br>
    <br>
    2. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner of
Customs" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014). Earlier the words "Commissioner of Customs" were
substituted by Act 22 of 1995, section 50, for the words "Collector of Customs"
(w.e.f. 26.05.1995).
    <br>
    <br>
    3. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2001 (14 of 2001), section 109(a), for "within three months"
(w.e.f. 11.05.2001).
    <br>

 Section 128A

Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 128A.  Procedure in appeal. -   </strong></p><p>   (1) The   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Commissioner (Appeals)] shall give anopportunity to the appellant to be heard if he so desires.  </p><p>   (2)   The   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Commissioner (Appeals)] may, atthe hearing of an appeal, allow the appellant to go into any ground of appealnot specified in the grounds of appeal, if the   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Commissioner (Appeals)] is satisfied that the omissionof that ground from the grounds of appeal was not wilful or unreasonable.  </p><p>   (3)   The   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Commissioner (Appeals) shall,after making such further inquiry as may be necessary, pass such order, as hethinks   <sup>    3   </sup>   [just and proper,-  </p><div><br>   (a) confirming, modifying or annulling the decision or order appealed against;or  </div><div><br>   (b) referring the matter back to the adjudicating authority with directions forfresh adjudication or decision, as the case may be, in the following cases,namely:-  </div><p></p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (i) where an order or decision has been passed without following the principlesof natural justice; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (ii) where no order or decision has been passed after re-assessment under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000202/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000031/1000002" alt="section17">section17</a>; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (iii) where an order of refund under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000202/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000044/1000002" alt="section 27">section 27</a> has been issued by creditingthe amount to Fund without recording any finding on the evidence produced bythe applicant.] :  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that an order enhancing any penalty or fine in lieu of confiscation orconfiscating goods of greater value or reducing the amount of refund shall notbe passed unless the appellant has been given a reasonable opportunity ofshowing cause against the proposed order :  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   further that where the   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Commissioner(Appeals)] is of opinion that any duty has not been levied or has beenshort-levied or erroneously refunded, no order requiring the appellant to payany duty not levied, short-levied or erroneously refunded shall be passedunless the appellant is given notice within the time-limit specified in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000202/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000046/1000002" alt="section28">section28</a> to show cause against the proposed order.  </p><p>(4) The order of the&nbsp;<sup>1</sup>[Commissioner(Appeals)] disposing of the appeal shall be in writing and shall state thepoints for determination, the decision thereon and the reasons for thedecision.</p><p><sup>4</sup>[(4A) The Commissioner (Appeals) shall, where it ispossible to do so, hear and decide every appeal within a period of six monthsfrom the date on which it is filed.]</p><p>(5)  On the disposal of the appeal, the&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 9.75px; vertical-align: super;">1</span>[Commissioner (Appeals)] shall communicate the orderpassed by him to the appellant, the adjudicating authority&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 9.75px; vertical-align: super;">5</span>[, the&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 9.75px; vertical-align: super;">6</span>[Principal ChiefCommissioner of Customs or Chief Commissioner of Customs] and the&nbsp;<span style="font-size: 9.75px; vertical-align: super;">7</span>[Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner ofCustoms]].</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. Substituted by Finance Act, 1995 (22 of 1995), section 50, for "Collector (Appeals)"(w.e.f. 26.05.1995).   <br>   <br>   2. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2001 (14 of 2001), section 110(a), for certain words(w.e.f. 11.05.2001).   <br>   <br>   3. Substituted by section 96  (w.e.f. 29-3-2018) of the Finance Act, 2018 (13 of 2018), for "just and proper, confirming, modifying or annulling thedecision or order appealed against".   <br>   <br>   4. Inserted by the Finance Act, 2001 (14 of 2001), section 110(b) (w.e.f. 11.05.2001).   <br>   <br>   5. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2005, section 69, for "and the Commissioner ofCustoms" (w.e.f. 13.05.2005).   <br>   <br>   6. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Chief Commissioner ofCustoms" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014).   <br>   <br>   7. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner ofCustoms" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014).  </div></span>

 Section 129

Data from Section 129:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 129.  Appellate Tribunal. -   </strong></p><p>   (1) The Central Government shall constitute an Appellate Tribunal to be called the Customs, Excise and   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Service Tax] Appellate Tribunal consisting of as many judicial and technical members as it thinks fit to exercise the powers and discharge the functions conferred on the Appellate Tribunal by this Act.  </p><p><sup>    2   </sup>   [(2)   A judicial member shall be a person who has for at least ten years held a judicial office in the territory of India or who has been a member of the   <sup>    3   </sup>   [Indian Legal Service]and has held a post in Grade I of that service or any equivalent or higher post for at least three years, or who has been an advocate for at least ten years.  </p><p><strong>    Explanation   </strong>   . - For the purposes of this sub-section, -  </p><div><br>   (i)   in computing the period during which a person has held judicial office in the territory of India, there shall be included any period, after he has held any judicial office, during which the person has been an advocate or has held the office of a member of a tribunal or any post, under the Union or a State, requiring special knowledge of law;  </div><p>   (ii)   in computing the period during which a person has been an advocate, there shall be included any period during which the person has held a judicial office, or the office of a member of a tribunal or any post, under the Union or a State, requiring special knowledge of law after he became an advocate.  </p><p>   (2A) A technical member shall be a person who has been a member of the Indian Customs and Central Excise Service, Group A, and has held the post of   <sup>    4   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] or Central Excise or any equivalent or higher post for at least three years.]  </p><p><sup>    5   </sup>   [(3)   The Central Government shall appoint -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)   a person who is or has been a Judge of a High Court; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)   one of the members of the Appellate Tribunal,  </p><div><br>   to be the President thereof.]      (4)   The Central Government may appoint one or more members of the Appellate Tribunal to be the Vice-President, or, as the case may be, Vice-Presidents, thereof.   <br>   <br>   <sup>    6   </sup>   [(4A) * * * *]   <br>   <br>   (5)   <sup>    7   </sup>   [A Vice-President] shall exercise such of the powers and perform such of the functions of the President as may be delegated to him by the President by a general or special order in writing.]   <br>   <br>   <sup>    8   </sup>   [(6) On ceasing to hold office, the President, Vice-President or other Member shall not be entitled to appear, act or plead before the Appellate Tribunal.]   <br>   <br>   <sup>    9   </sup>   [(7) Notwithstanding anything contained in this Act, the qualifications, appointment, term of office, salaries and allowances, resignation, removal and the other terms and conditions of service of the President, Vice-President or other Members of the Appellate Tribunal appointed after the commencement of Part XIV of Chapter VI of the Finance Act, 2017,shall be governed by the provisions of section 184 of that Act:   <div><br>    <strong>     Provided    </strong>    that the President. Vice-President and Member appointed before the commencement of Part XIV of Chapter VI of the Finance Act, 2017, shall continue to be governed by the provisions of this Act, and the rules made thereunder as if the provisions of section 184 of the Finance Act, 2017 had not come into force.]    <br>    <br>    <div class="footnotes"><p>   1. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003), section 119(a), for "Gold (Control)"(w.e.f. 14.05.2003).    </p><p>      2. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1984 (21 of 1984), section 39(a), for sub-section (2)(w.e.f. 11.05.1984).       </p><p>      3. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003), section 119(b), for "Central Legal Service" (w.e.f. 14.05.2003).    </p><p>      4. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), for "Commissioner of Customs" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014). Earlier the words "Commissioner of Customs" were substituted by Act 22 of 1995, section50, for the words "Collector of Customs" (w.e.f. 26.05.1995).<span style="font-size: 12px;">&nbsp;</span></p><p> 5. Earlier sub-section (4A) was inserted by Act 21 of 1984, section39(b) (w.e.f. 11.05.1984)    </p><p>7. No. 1696(E), dated 26-5-2017)    </p></div></div></div></span>

<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 129A.  Appeals to the Appellate Tribunal. -    <br>   </strong></p><p>   (1) Any person aggrieved by any of the following orders may appeal to theAppellate Tribunal against such order -  </p><p order passed by the Board or the   <sup>    3   </sup>   [Appellate Commissioner of Customs] under <a target="_blank" and the Central Government shall deal with such appeal ormatter under <a target="_blank"  Section 129B

Data from Section 129B:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 129B.  Orders of Appellate Tribunal.-    <br>   </strong></p><p>   (1) The Appellate Tribunal may, after giving the parties to the appeal, anopportunity of being heard, pass such orders thereon as it thinks fit,confirming, modifying or annulling the decision or order appealed against ormay refer the case back to the authority which passed such decision or orderwith such directions as the Appellate Tribunal may think fit, for a freshadjudication or decision, as the case may be, after taking additional evidence,if necessary.  </p><p><sup>    1   </sup>   [(1A)   The Appellate Tribunal may, ifsufficient cause is shown, at any stage of hearing of an appeal, grant time tothe parties or any of them and adjourn the hearing of the appeal for reasons tobe recorded in writing :  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that no such adjournment shall be granted more than three times to aparty during hearing of the appeal.]  </p><p>   (2) The Appellate Tribunal may, at any time within   <sup>    2   </sup>   [six months] from the date of the order, with a view torectifying any mistake apparent from the record, amend any order passed by itunder sub-section (1) and shall make such amendments if the mistake is broughtto its notice by the   <sup>    3   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customsor Commissioner of Customs] or the other party to the appeal:  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that an amendment which has the effect of enhancing the assessment orreducing a refund or otherwise increasing the liability of the other partyshall not be made under this sub-section, unless the Appellate Tribunal hasgiven notice to him of its intention to do so and has allowed him a reasonableopportunity of being heard.  </p><p><sup>    4   </sup>   [(2A) The Appellate Tribunal shall, where it ispossible to do so, hear and decide every appeal within a period of three yearsfrom the date on which such appeal is filed :  </p><p><sup>    5   </sup>   [* * * * * * * * *]  </p><p>   (3)   The Appellate Tribunal shall send a copy of every order passedunder this section to the   <sup>    6   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner ofCustoms or Commissioner of Customs] and the other party to the appeal.  </p><p>   (4)   Save as otherwise provided in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000205/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000205/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000217/1000002" alt="section 130E">section 130E</a>,orders passed by the Appellate Tribunal on appeal shall be final.  </p><div class="footnotes">   1. Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 129B.  Orders of Appellate Tribunal.-    <br>   </strong></p><p>   (1) The Appellate Tribunal may, after giving the parties to the appeal, anopportunity of being heard, pass such orders thereon as it thinks fit,confirming, modifying or annulling the decision or order appealed against ormay refer the case back to the authority which passed such decision or orderwith such directions as the Appellate Tribunal may think fit, for a freshadjudication or decision, as the case may be, after taking additional evidence,if necessary.  </p><p><sup>    1   </sup>   [(1A)   The Appellate Tribunal may, ifsufficient cause is shown, at any stage of hearing of an appeal, grant time tothe parties or any of them and adjourn the hearing of the appeal for reasons tobe recorded in writing :  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that no such adjournment shall be granted more than three times to aparty during hearing of the appeal.]  </p><p>   (2) The Appellate Tribunal may, at any time within   <sup>    2   </sup>   [six months] from the date of the order, with a view torectifying any mistake apparent from the record, amend any order passed by itunder sub-section (1) and shall make such amendments if the mistake is broughtto its notice by the   <sup>    3   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customsor Commissioner of Customs] or the other party to the appeal:  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that an amendment which has the effect of enhancing the assessment orreducing a refund or otherwise increasing the liability of the other partyshall not be made under this sub-section, unless the Appellate Tribunal hasgiven notice to him of its intention to do so and has allowed him a reasonableopportunity of being heard.  </p><p><sup>    4   </sup>   [(2A) The Appellate Tribunal shall, where it ispossible to do so, hear and decide every appeal within a period of three yearsfrom the date on which such appeal is filed :  </p><p><sup>    5   </sup>   [* * * * * * * * *]  </p><p>   (3)   The Appellate Tribunal shall send a copy of every order passedunder this section to the   <sup>    6   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner ofCustoms or Commissioner of Customs] and the other party to the appeal.  </p><p>   (4)   Save as otherwise provided in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000205/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000205/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000217/1000002" alt="section 130E">section 130E</a>,orders passed by the Appellate Tribunal on appeal shall be final.  </p><div class="footnotes">   1.  Section 129C

Data from Section 129C:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 129C.  Procedure of Appellate Tribunal. -</strong></p><p>   (1) The powers and functions of the Appellate Tribunal may be exercised anddischarged by Benches constituted by the President from amongst the membersthereof.  </p><p>   (2)  Subject to the provisions contained in   <sup>    1   </sup>   [sub-section (4)], a Bench shall consist of onejudicial member and one technical member.  </p><p><sup>    2   </sup>   [(3) * * * *]  </p><p>   (4)   The President or any other member of the Appellate Tribunalauthorised in this behalf by the President may, sitting singly, dispose of anycase which has been allotted to the Bench of which he is a member where -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  the value of the goods confiscated without option havingbeen given to the owner of the goods to pay a fine in lieu of confiscationunder <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000206/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000185/1000002" alt="section 125">section 125</a>; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  in any disputed case, other than a case where thedetermination of any question having a relation to the rate of duty of customsor to the value of goods for purposes of assessment is in issue or is one ofthe points in issue, the difference in duty involved or the duty involved; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (c)  the amount of fine or penalty involved,  </p><p>   does not exceed   <sup>    3   </sup>   [fifty lakh rupees].  </p><p><sup>    4   </sup>   [(5)   If the members of a Bench differ inopinion on any point, the point shall be decided according to the opinion ofthe majority, if there is a majority; but if the members are equally divided,they shall state the point or points on which they differ and make a referenceto the President who shall either hear the point or points himself or refer thecase for hearing on such point or points by one or more of the other members ofthe Appellate Tribunal and such point or points shall be decided according to theopinion of the majority of these members of the Appellate Tribunal who haveheard the case, including those who first heard it.]  </p><p>   (6)   Subject to the provisions of this Act, the Appellate Tribunalshall have power to regulate its own procedure and the procedure of the Benchesthereof in all matters arising out of the exercise of its powers or of thedischarge of its functions, including the places at which the Benches shallhold their sittings.  </p><p>   (7)   The Appellate Tribunal shall, for the purposes of dischargingits functions, have the same powers as are vested in a court under the Code ofCivil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), when trying a suit in respect of thefollowing matters, namely :-  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a) discovery and inspection;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b) enforcing the attendance of any person and examining him onoath;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (c) compelling the production of books of account and otherdocuments; and  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (d) issuing commissions.  </p><p>(8)   Any proceeding before the Appellate Tribunal shall be deemed tobe a judicial proceeding within the meaning of sections 193 and 228 and for thepurpose of section 196 of the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860), and the AppellateTribunal shall be deemed to be a Civil Court for all the purposes of section195 and Chapter XXVI of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (2 of 1974).</p><p><br></p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1995 (22 of 1995), section 65(a), for "sub-section (3) and(4)" (w.e.f. 26.05.1995).   <br>   <br>   2. Sub-section (3) omitted by the Finance Act, 1995 (22 of 1995), section 65 (b) (w.e.f.26.05.1995). Earlier sub-section (3) was amended by Act 80 of 1985, section10(a) (w.e.f. 27.12.1985).   <br>   <br>   3. Substituted by the Finance Act, 2013 (17 of 2013), section 77, for "ten lakh rupees"(w.e.f. 10.05.2013). Earlier the words "ten lakh rupees" were substituted byAct 33 of 1996, section 66, for the words "one lakh rupees" (w.e.f.28.09.1996); the words "one lakh ruppes" were substituted by Act 38 of 1993,section 43(2), for the words "fifty thousand rupees" (w.e.f. 13.05.1953); thewords "fifty thousand rupees" were substituted by Act 21 of 1984, section 41,for the words "ten thousand rupees" (w.e.f. 11.05.1984).   <br>   <br>   4. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1990 (12 of 1990), section 62(a), for sub-section (5)(w.e.f. 31.05.1990). Earlier sub-section (5) was amended by Act 80 of 1985,section 10(b) (w.e.f. 27.12.1985).   <br>   <br>  </div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 129C.  Procedure of Appellate Tribunal. -</strong></p><p>   (1) The powers and functions of the Appellate Tribunal may be exercised anddischarged by Benches constituted by the President from amongst the membersthereof.  </p><p>   (2)  Subject to the provisions contained in   <sup>    1   </sup>   [sub-section (4)], a Bench shall consist of onejudicial member and one technical member.  </p><p><sup>    2   </sup>   [(3) * * * *]  </p><p>   (4)   The President or any other member of the Appellate Tribunalauthorised in this behalf by the President may, sitting singly, dispose of anycase which has been allotted to the Bench of which he is a member where -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  the value of the goods confiscated without option havingbeen given to the owner of the goods to pay a fine in lieu of confiscationunder <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000206/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000185/1000002" alt="section 125">section 125</a>;  Section 129DD

Data from Section 129DD:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong><sup>1   </sup>   [Section 129DD. Revision by Central Government.-</strong><br></p><p>(1) The Central Government may, on the application of any person aggrieved by any order passed under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000202/1000002" alt="section 128A">section 128A</a>, where the order is of the nature referred to in the first proviso to sub-section (1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000204/1000002" alt="section 129A">section 129A</a>, annul or modify such order.</p><div><br>   <sup>    2   </sup>   [   <strong>    Provided   </strong>   that the Central Government may in its discretion, refuse to admit an application in respect of an order where the amount of duty or fine or penalty, determined by such order does not exceed five thousand rupees.]  </div><div><br>   <strong>    Explanation   </strong>   . - For the purposes of this sub-section, "order passed under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000202/1000002" alt="section 128A">section 128A</a>" includes an order passed under that section before the commencement of section 40 of the Finance Act, 1984**, against which an appeal has not been preferred before such commencement and could have been, if the said section had not come into force, preferred after such commencement, to the Appellate Tribunal.   <br>   <br>   <sup>    3   </sup>   [(1A) The   <sup>    4   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] may, if he is of the opinion that an order passed by the Commissioner (Appeals) under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000202/1000002" alt="section 128A">section 128A</a> is not legal or proper, direct the proper officer to make an application on his behalf to the Central Government for revision of such order.]   <br>   <br>   <p>    (2)   An application under sub-section (1) shall be made within three months from the date of the communication to the applicant of the order against which the application is being made :   </p><p><strong>     Provided    </strong>    that the Central Government may, if it is satisfied that the applicant was prevented by sufficient cause from presenting the application within the aforesaid period of three months, allow it to be presented within a further period of three months.</p><sup>    5   </sup>   [(3)   An application under sub-section (1)shall be in such form and shall be verified in such manner as may be specified by rules made in this behalf and shall be accompanied by a fee of, -  </div><div><p style="padding-left: 40px;">    (a)  two hundred rupees, where the amount of duty and interest demanded, fine or penalty levied by an officer of customs in the case to which the application relates is one lakh rupees or less;   </p>   (b)  one thousand rupees, where the amount of duty and interest demanded, fine or penalty levied by an officer of customs in the case to which the application relates is more than one lakh rupees :&nbsp;</div><div><br></div><div>&nbsp;  <strong>Provided   </strong>   that no such fee shall be payable in the case of an application referred to in sub-section (1A).]   <br>   <br>   (4)   The Central Government may, of its own motion, annul or modify any order referred to in sub-section (1).   <br>   <br>   (5)   No order enhancing any penalty or fine in lieu of confiscation or confiscating goods of greater value shall be passed under this section, -  </div><div><p style="padding-left: 40px;">    (a)  in any case in which an order passed under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000202/1000002" alt="section 128A">section 128A</a> has enhanced any penalty or fine in lieu of confiscation or has confiscated goods of greater value, and   </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">    (b)  in any other case, unless the person affected by the proposed order has been given notice to show cause against it within one year from the date of the order sought to be annulled or modified.   </p>   (6)   Where the Central Government is of opinion that any duty of customs has not been levied or has been short-levied, no order levying or enhancing the duty shall be made under this section unless the person affected by the proposed order is given notice to show cause against it within the time limit specified in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000209/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000046/1000002" alt="section 28">section 28</a>.]   <br>   <br>   <div class="footnotes">    1. Inserted by the Finance Act, 1984 (21 of 1984), section 43 (w.e.f. 11.05.1984).    <br>    <br>    2. Inserted by the Finance Act, 1999 (27 of 1999), section 110(a) (w.e.f. 11.05.1999).    <br>    <br>    ** Ed. Date of commencement of section 40 of the Finance Act, 1984 is 11th May,1984.    <br>    <br>    3. Inserted by the Finance Act, 1999 (27 of 1999), section 110(b) (w.e.f. 11.05.1999).    <br>    <br>    4. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner of Customs" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014).    <br>    <br>    5. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1999 (27 of 1999), section 110(c), for sub-section (3)(w.e.f. 11.05.1999).   </div></div></span>

 Section 129E

Data from Section 129E:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   <sup>    1</sup>[Section 129E. Deposit of certain percentage of duty demanded or penalty imposed before filing appeal. -<br>  </strong></p><p>- The Tribunal or the Commissioner (Appeals), as the case may be, shall not entertain any appeal, -</p><p>&nbsp; &nbsp;(i) under sub-section (1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000210/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000201/1000002" alt="section 128">section 128</a>, unless the appellant has deposited seven and a half per cent. of the duty, in case where duty or duty and penalty are in dispute, or penalty, where such penalty is in dispute, in pursuance of a decision or an order passed by an officer of customs lower in rank than the</p><p><sup>   2</sup>[Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs];</p><p>(ii) against the decision or order referred to in clause (a) of sub-section (1)of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000210/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000204/1000002" alt="section 129A">section 129A</a>, unless the appellant has deposited seven and a half per cent. of the duty, in case where duty or duty and penalty are in dispute, or penalty, where such penalty is in dispute, in pursuance of the decision or order appealed against;</p><div>(iii) against the decision or order referred to in clause (b) of sub-section(1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000210/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000204/1000002" alt="section 129A">section 129A</a>, unless the appellant has deposited ten per cent. of the duty, in case where duty or duty and penalty are in dispute, or penalty, where such penalty is in dispute, in pursuance of the decision or order appealed against :<br></div><div><strong><br></strong></div><div><strong>Provided   </strong>   that the amount required to be deposited under this section shall not exceed rupees ten crores :<br></div><div>&nbsp;</div><div><strong>Provided   </strong>   further that the provisions of this section shall not apply to the stay applications and appeals pending before any appellate authority prior to the commencement of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014.]<br></div><div><br>   <div class="footnotes">    1. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 89, for section 129E (w.e.f.06.08.2014). Earlier section 129E was amended by Act 55 of 1991, section 10(w.e.f. 23.12.1991), by Act 22 of 1995, section 50 (w.e.f. 26.05.1995), by Act27 of 1999, section 110(c) (w.e.f. 11.05.1999) and by Act 14 of 2001, section112 (w.e.f. 11.05.2001). Section 129E, before substitution by Act 25 of 2014,stood as under:    <br>    "129E. Deposit, pending appeal, of duty and interest, demanded or penalty levied.- Where in any appeal under this Chapter, the decision or order appealed against relates to any duty and interest demanded in respect of goods which arenot under the control of the customs authorities or any penalty levied under this Act, the person desirous of appealing against such decision or order shall, pending the appeal, deposit with the proper officer duty and interest demanded or the penalty levied:    <br>    Provided that where in any particular case, the Commissioner (Appeals) or the Appellate Tribunal is of opinion that the deposit of duty and interest demanded or penalty levied would cause undue hardship to such person, the Commissioner(Appeals) or, as the case may be, the Appellate Tribunal may dispense with such deposit subject to such conditions as he or it may deem fit to impose so as to safeguard the interests of revenue:    <br>    Provided further that where an application is filed before the Commissioner(Appeals) for dispensing with the deposit of duty and interest demanded or penalty levied under the first proviso, the Commissioner (Appeals) shall, where it is possible to do so, decide such application within thirty days from the date of its filing."    <br>    <br>    2. Substituted (w.e.f. 6-8-2014) for the words" Commissioner of Customs" by s. 78 of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014).    <br>    <br>   </div></div></span>

 Section 129EE

Data from Section 129EE:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><br></p><p><strong>   <sup>    1</sup>[Section 129EE. Interest on delayed refund of amount deposited under section 129E. -</strong></p><p>Where an amount deposited by the appellant under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000211/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000210/1000002" alt="section 129E">section 129E</a> is required to be refunded consequent upon the order of the appellate authority, there shall be paid to the appellant interest at such rate, not below five per cent. and not exceeding thirty-six per cent. per annum as is for the time being fixed by the Central Government, by notification in the Official Gazette, on such amount from the date of payment of the amount till, the date of refund of such amount:</p><div><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that the amount deposited under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000211/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000210/1000002" alt="section 129E">section 129E</a>, prior to the commencement of the Finance (No. 2) Act, 2014, shall continue to be governed by the provisions of section 129EE as it stood before the commencement of the said Act.]   <br>   <br>   <div class="footnotes">    1. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 90, for section 129EE (w.e.f.06.08.2014). Earlier section 129EE was inserted by Act 18 of 2008, section 73(w.e.f. 10.05.2008). Section 129EE, before substitution by Act 25 of 2014,stood as under:    <br>    "129EE. Interest on delayed refund of amount deposited under the proviso to section 129E.- Where an amount deposited by the appellant in pursuance of an order passed by the Commissioner (Appeals) or the Appellate Tribunal(hereinafter referred to as appellate authority), under the first proviso to section 129E, is required to be refunded consequent upon the order of the appellate authority and such amount is not refunded within three months from the date of communication of such order to the adjudicating authority, unless the operation of the order of the appellate authority is stayed by a superior court or tribunal, there shall be paid to the appellant interest at the rate specified in section 27A after the expiry of three months from the date of communication of the order of the appellant authority, till the date of refund of such amount."    <br>    <br>   </div></div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><br></p><p><strong>   <sup>    1</sup>[Section 129EE. Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Section 130. Appeal to High Court. -   <br>  </strong></p><p>   (1) An appeal shall lie to the High Court from every order passed in appeal by the Appellate Tribunal on or after the 1st day of July, 2003 (not being an order relating, among other things, to the determination of any question having a relation to the rate of duty of customs or to the value of goods for the purposes of assessment), if the High Court is satisfied that the case involves a substantial question of law.  </p><p>   (2)  The   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] or the other party aggrieved by any order passed bythe Appellate Tribunal may file an appeal to the High Court and such appeal under this sub-section shall be -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  filed within one hundred and eighty days from the date on which the order appealed against is received by the   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] or the other party;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  accompanied by a fee of two hundred rupees where such appeal is filed by the other party;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (c)  in the form of a memorandum of appeal precisely stating therein the substantial question of law involved.  </p><p><sup>    3   </sup>   [(2A)  The High Court may admit an appeal after the expiry of the period of one hundred and eighty days referred to in clause(a) of sub-section (2), if it is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not filing the same within that period.]  </p><p>   (3)  Where the High Court is satisfied that a substantial question of law is involved in any case, it shall formulate that question.  </p><p>   (4)   The appeal shall be heard only on the question so formulated,and the respondents shall, at the hearing of the appeal, be allowed to argue that the case does not involve such question:  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that nothing in this sub-section shall be deemed to take away or abridge the power of the Court to hear, for reasons to be recorded, the appeal on any other substantial question of law not formulated by it, if it is satisfied that the case involves such question.  </p><p>   (5)  The High Court shall decide the question of law so formulated and deliver such judgment thereon containing the grounds on which such decision is founded and may award such cost as it deems fit.  </p><p>   (6)  The High Court may determine any issue which -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  has not been determined by the Appellate Tribunal; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  has been wrongly determined by the Appellate Tribunal, by reason of a decision on such question of law as is referred to in sub-section (1).</p><p>(7)  When an appeal has been filed before the High Court, it shall be heard by a bench of not less than two Judges of the High Court, and shall be decided in accordance with the opinion of such Judges or of the majority, if any, of such Judges.</p><p>(8)  Where there is no such majority, the Judges shall state the point of law upon which they differ and the case shall, then, be heard upon that point only by one or more of the other Judges of the High Court and such point shall be decided according to the opinion of the majority of the Judges who have heard the case including those who first heard it.</p><p>(9)  Save as otherwise provided in this Act, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) relating to appeals to the High Court shall,as far as may be, apply in the case of appeals under this section.]</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. Section 130 was earlier amended by Act 27 of 1999, section 111 (w.e.f.11.05.1999) and was substituted by the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003), section 120 (w.e.f.14.05.2003).   <br>   <br>   2. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner of Customs" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014).   <br>   <br>   3. Inserted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2009 (33 of 2009), section 87 (w.e.f. 01.07.2003).   <br>   <br>  </div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Section 130. Appeal to High Court. -   <br>  </strong></p><p>   (1) An appeal shall lie to the High Court from every order passed in appeal by the Appellate Tribunal on or after the 1st day of July, 2003 (not being an order relating, among other things, to the determination of any question having a relation to the rate of duty of customs or to the value of goods for the purposes of assessment), if the High Court is satisfied that the case involves a substantial question of law.  </p><p>   (2)  The   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] or the other party aggrieved by any order passed bythe Appellate Tribunal may file an appeal to the High Court and such appeal under this sub-section shall be -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  filed within one hundred and eighty days from the date on which the order appealed against is received by the   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] or the other party;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  accompanied by a fee of two hundred rupees where such appeal is filed by the other party;  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (c)  in the form of a memorandum of appeal precisely stating therein the substantial question of law involved.  </p><p><sup>    3   </sup>   [(2A)  The High Court may admit an appeal after the expiry of the period of one hundred and eighty days referred to in clause(a) of sub-section (2), if it is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not filing the same within that period.]  </p><p>   (3)  Where the High Court is satisfied that a substantial question of law is involved in any case, it shall formulate that question.  </p><p>   (4)   The appeal shall be heard only on the question so formulated,and the respondents shall, at the hearing of the appeal, be allowed to argue that the case does not involve such question:  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that nothing in this sub-section shall be deemed to take away or abridge the power of the Court to hear, for reasons to be recorded, the appeal on any other substantial question of law not formulated by it, if it is satisfied that the case involves such question.  </p><p>   (5)  The High Court shall decide the question of law so formulated and deliver such judgment thereon containing the grounds on which such decision is founded and may award such cost as it deems fit.  </p><p>   (6)  The High Court may determine any issue which -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  has not been determined by the Appellate Tribunal; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  has been wrongly determined by the Appellate Tribunal, by reason of a decision on such question of law as is referred to in sub-section (1).</p><p>(7)  When an appeal has been filed before the High Court, it shall be heard by a bench of not less than two Judges of the High Court, and shall be decided in accordance with the opinion of such Judges or of the majority, if any, of such Judges.</p><p>(8)  Where there is no such majority, the Judges shall state the point of law upon which they differ and the case shall, then, be heard upon that point only by one or more of the other Judges of the High Court and such point shall be decided according to the opinion of the majority of the Judges who have heard the case including those who first heard it.</p><p>(9)  Save as otherwise provided in this Act, the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908) relating to appeals to the High Court shall,as far as may be, apply in the case of appeals under this section.]</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. Section 130 was earlier amended by Act 27 of 1999, section 111 (w.e.f.11.05.1999) and was substituted by the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003), section 120 (w.e.f.14.05.2003).   <br>   <br>   2. Substituted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner of Customs" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014).   <br>   <br>   3. Inserted by the Finance (No.2) Act, 2009 (33 of 2009), section 87 (w.e.f. 01.07.2003).   <br>   <br>  </div></span>

<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><div id="content"><strong>    <sup>     1    </sup>    [Section 130A. eightydays of the date upon which he is served with notice of an order under <a target="_blank" assessment), by application in the prescribed form,accompanied, where the application is made by the other party, by a fee of twohundred rupees, apply to the High Court to direct the Appellate Tribunal torefer to the High Court any question of law arising from such order of theTribunal.   <br>   <br>   (2)  The   <sup>    2   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs orCommissioner of Customs] or the other party applying to the High Court undersub-section (1) shall clearly state the question of law which he seeks to bereferred to the High Court and shall also specify the paragraph in the order ofthe Appellate Tribunal relevant to the question sought to be referred.   <br>   <br>   (3)  On receipt of notice that an application has been made undersub-section (1), the person against whom such application has been made, may,notwithstanding that he may not have filed such application, file, withinforty-five days of the receipt of the notice, a memorandum of cross-objectionsverified in the prescribed manner against any part of the order in relation towhich an application for reference has been made and such memorandum shall bedisposed of by the High Court as if it were an application presented within thetime specified in sub-section (1).   <br>   <br>   <sup>    4   </sup>   [(3A) The High Court may admit an application or permitthe filing of a memorandum of cross-objections after the expiry of the relevantperiod referred to in sub-section (1) or sub-section (3), if it is satisfiedthat there was sufficient cause for not filing the same within that period.]   <br>   <br>   (4)  If, on an application made under sub-section (1), the High Courtdirects the Appellate Tribunal to refer the question of law raised in theapplication, the Appellate Tribunal shall, within one hundred and twenty daysof the receipt of such direction, draw up a statement of the case and refer itto the High Court.]   <br>   <br>   <div class="footnotes">  Section 130B

Data from Section 130B:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <br>
  <b>
   Section 130B.  Power of High Court or Supreme
Court to require statement to be amended. -
   <br>
  </b>
  <br>
  If the High Court or the Supreme Court is not satisfied that the statements in
a case referred to it are sufficient to enable it to determine the questions
raised thereby, the Court may refer the case back to the Appellate Tribunal for
the purpose of making such additions thereto or alterations therein as it may
direct in that behalf.
 
</span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <br>
  <b>
   Section 130B.  Power of High Court or Supreme
Court to require statement to be amended. -
   <br>
  </b>
  <br>
  If the High Court or the Supreme Court is not satisfied that the statements in
a case referred to it are sufficient to enable it to determine the questions
raised thereby, the Court may refer the case back to the Appellate Tribunal for
the purpose of making such additions thereto or alterations therein as it may
direct in that behalf.
 
</span>



 Section 130C

<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 130C.  Case before High Court to beheard by not less than two judges. -</strong></p><p>(1) When any case has been referred to the High Court&nbsp;<sup>1</sup>[under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000215/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000215/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000213/1000002" alt="section 130A">section 130A</a>] it shall be heardby a Bench of not less than two judges of the High Court and shall be decidedin accordance with the opinion of such judges or of the majority, if any, ofsuch judges.</p><p>(2)  Where there is no such majority, the judges shall state the point oflaw upon which they differ and the case shall then be heard upon that pointonly by one or more of the other judges of the High Court, and such point shallbe decided according to the opinion of the majority of the judges who haveheard the case including those who first heard it.</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. Substituted by the Finance Act, 1999 (27 of 1999), section 113.  </div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 130C.  Case before High Court to beheard by not less than two judges. -</strong></p><p>(1) When any case has been referred to the High Court&nbsp;<sup>1</sup>[under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000215/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000215/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000213/1000002" alt="section 130A">section 130A</a>] it shall be heardby a Bench of not less than two judges of the High Court and shall be decidedin accordance with the opinion of such judges or of the majority, if any, ofsuch judges.</p><p>(2)  Where there is no such majority, the judges shall state the point oflaw upon which they differ and the case shall then be heard upon that pointonly by one or more of the other judges of the High Court, and such point shallbe decided according to the opinion of the majority of the judges who haveheard the case including those who first heard it.</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1.  Section 130D

Data from Section 130D:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 130D. Decision of High Court or Supreme Court on the case stated. -</strong></p><p>(1) The High Court or the Supreme Court hearing any such case shall decide the questions of law raised therein, and shall deliver its judgment thereon containing the grounds on which such decision is founded and a copy of the judgment shall be sent under the seal of the Court and the signature of the Registrar to the Appellate Tribunal which shall pass such orders as are necessary to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment. <sup>1</sup>[(1A) Where the High Court delivers a judgment in an appeal filed before it under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000216/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a>, effect shall be given to the order passed on the appeal by the proper officer on the basis of a certified copy of the judgment.]</p><p>(2) The costs of any&nbsp;<sup>2</sup>[reference to the High Court or an appeal to the High Courtor the Supreme Court as the case may be] which shall not include the fee for making the reference shall be in the discretion of the Court.</p><div><br>  </div><div class="footnotes"><div>    1. Inserted (w.e.f. 1-7-2003) by s. 122 of the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003).   </div><div><br>    <div>     2. Substituted (w.e.f. 14-5-2003) by s. 122 of the Finance Act, 2003 (32 of 2003).    </div></div></div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>   Section 130D. Decision of High Court or Supreme Court on the case stated. -</strong></p><p>(1) The High Court or the Supreme Court hearing any such case shall decide the questions of law raised therein, and shall deliver its judgment thereon containing the grounds on which such decision is founded and a copy of the judgment shall be sent under the seal of the Court and the signature of the Registrar to the Appellate Tribunal which shall pass such orders as are necessary to dispose of the case in conformity with such judgment. <sup>1</sup>[(1A) Where the High Court delivers a judgment in an appeal filed before it under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000216/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a>, effect shall be given to the order passed on the appeal by the proper officer on the basis of a certified copy of the judgment.]</p><p>(2) The costs of any&nbsp;<sup>2</sup>[reference to the High Court or an appeal to the High Courtor the Supreme Court as the case may be] which shall not include the fee for making the reference shall be in the discretion of the Court.</p><div><br>  </div><div class="footnotes"><div>    1.  Section 130F

Data from Section 130F:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 130F.   Hearing before Supreme Court. -   </strong></p><p>   (1) The provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), relatingto appeals to the Supreme Court shall, so far as may be, apply in the case ofappeals under section 130E as they apply in the case of appeals from decrees ofa High Court:  </p><p><strong>   Provided&nbsp;</strong>that nothing in this sub-section shall be deemed to affect theprovisions of sub-section (1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000216/1000002" alt="section 130D">section 130D</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000219/1000002" alt="section 131">section 131</a>.</p><div>   (2)   The costs of the appeal shall be in the discretion of theSupreme Court.  </div><div><br>   (3)   Where the judgment of the High Court is varied or reversed inthe appeal, effect shall be given to the order of the Supreme Court in themanner provided in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000216/1000002" alt="section 130D">section 130D</a> in the case of a judgment of the High Court.  </div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 130F.   Hearing before Supreme Court. -   </strong></p><p>   (1) The provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (5 of 1908), relatingto appeals to the Supreme Court shall, so far as may be, apply in the case ofappeals under section 130E as they apply in the case of appeals from decrees ofa High Court:  </p><p><strong>   Provided&nbsp;</strong>that nothing in this sub-section shall be deemed to affect theprovisions of sub-section (1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000216/1000002" alt="section 130D">section 130D</a> or <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000219/1000002" alt="section 131">section 131</a>.</p><div>   (2)   The costs of the appeal shall be in the discretion of theSupreme Court.  </div><div><br>   (3)   Where the judgment of the High Court is varied or reversed inthe appeal, effect shall be given to the order of the Supreme Court in themanner provided in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000218/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000216/1000002" alt="section 130D">section 130D</a> in the case of a judgment of the High Court.  </div></span>



 Section 131

Data from Section 131:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 131.   Sums due to be paid notwithstanding reference, etc.-   </strong></p><p>Notwithstanding that a reference has been made to the High Court or the SupremeCourt or an appeal has been preferred to the Supreme Court,</p><p><sup>   1</sup>[under this Act before the commencement of the NationalTax Tribunal Act, 2005] sums due to the Government as a result of an orderpassed under sub-section (1) of <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000219/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000205/1000002" alt="section 129B">section 129B</a> shall be payable in accordancewith the order so passed.</p><p><br></p><div class="footnotes">   1. To be inserted (from a date to be notified) by s. 30 read with Schedule to the National Tax Tribunal Act, 2005 (49 of 2005).   <br>  </div></span>



Component 2:

 Section 131A

Data from Section 131A:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <p>
   <b>
    Section 131A.   Exclusion of time taken for copy. -
    <br>
   </b>
  </p>
  <p>
   In computing the period of limitation specified for an appeal or application
under this Chapter, the day on which the order complained of was served, and if
the party preferring the appeal or making the application was not furnished
with a copy of the order when the notice of the order was served upon him, the
time requisite for obtaining a copy of such order shall be excluded.
  </p>
 
</span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <p>
   <b>
    Section 131A.   Exclusion of time taken for copy. -
    <br>
   </b>
  </p>
  <p>
   In computing the period of limitation specified for an appeal or application
under this Chapter, the day on which the order complained of was served, and if
the party preferring the appeal or making the application was not furnished
with a copy of the order when the notice of the order was served upon him, the
time requisite for obtaining a copy of such order shall be excluded.
  </p>
 
</span>



 Section 131B

Data from Section 131B:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><p><strong>    Section 131B.  Transfer of certain pending proceedings and transitionalprovisions. -    <br>   </strong></p><p>   (1) Every appeal which is pending immediately before the appointed day beforethe Board under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000201/1000002" alt="section 128">section 128</a>, as it stood immediately before that day, and anymatter arising out of or connected with such appeal and which is so pendingshall stand transferred on that day to the Appellate Tribunal and the AppellateTribunal may proceed with such appeal or matter from the stage at which it wason that day:  </p><p>   Provided that the appellant may demand that before proceeding further with thatappeal or matter, he may be re-heard.  </p><p>   (2)   Every proceeding which is pending immediately before theappointed day before the Central Government under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000219/1000002" alt="section 131">section 131</a>, as it stoodimmediately before that day, and any matter arising out of or connected with suchproceeding and which is so pending shall stand transferred on that day to theAppellate Tribunal and the Appellate Tribunal may proceed with such proceedingor matter from the stage at which it was on that day as if such proceeding ormatter were an appeal filed before it :  </p><p><strong>    Provided   </strong>   that if any such proceeding or matter relates to an order where -  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (a)  the value of the goods confiscated without option having been givento the owner of the goods to pay a fine in lieu of confiscation under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000185/1000002" alt="section125">section125</a>; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (b)  in any disputed case, other than a case where the determination ofany question having a relation to the rate of duty of customs or to the valueof goods for purposes of assessment is in issue or is one of the points inissue, the difference in duty involved or the duty involved; or  </p><p style="padding-left: 40px;">   (c)  the amount of fine or penalty determined by such order,  </p><div><br>   does not exceed ten thousand rupees, such proceeding or matter shall continueto be dealt with by the Central Government as if the said <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000219/1000002" alt="section 131">section 131</a> had not beensubstituted :   <p><strong>     Provided    </strong>    further that the applicant or the other party may make a demand to theAppellate Tribunal that before proceeding further with that proceeding ormatter, he may be re-heard.   </p>   (3)   Every proceeding which is pending immediately before theappointed day before the Board or the   <sup>    1   </sup>   [PrincipalCommissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] under <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000212/1000002" alt="section 130">section 130</a>, as itstood immediately before that day, and any matter arising out of or connectedwith such proceeding and which is so pending shall continue to be dealt with bythe Board or the   <sup>    1   </sup>   [Principal Commissioner of Customs orCommissioner of Customs], as the case may be, as if the said section had notbeen substituted.   <br>   <br>   (4)   Any person who immediately before the appointed day wasauthorised to appear in any appeal or proceeding transferred under sub-section(1) or sub-section (2) shall, notwithstanding anything contained in <a target="_blank" href="http://taxinformation.cbic.gov.in/suneditor/Acts/1000221/../../../content-page/explore-act/1000247/1000002" alt="section146A">section146A</a>, have the right to appear before the Appellate Tribunal in relation to suchappeal or proceeding.   <br>   <br>   <div class="footnotes">    1. Substituted by Finance (No.2) Act, 2014 (25 of 2014), section 78, for "Commissioner ofCustoms" (w.e.f. 06.08.2014). Earlier the words "Commissioner of Customs" weresubstituted by Act 22 of 1995, section 50, for the words "Collector of Customs"(w.e.f. 26.05.1995).   </div></div></span>

by the
   <sup>
    2

Commissioner of Customs] under the provisions of this Chapter.

   <sup>
    2
   </sup>
   [Principal Commissioner of
Customs or Commissioner of Customs]  has not filed an appeal, application,

   <sup>
    2
   </sup>
   Principal
Commissioner of Customs or Commissioner of Customs] from filing any appeal,

similar issues or questions of law.

   <sup>
    2

   <sup>
    2

instructions or directions issued under sub-section (1).
  </p>

20th   day of October, 2010, but before the date on which the Finance
Bill, 2011 receives the assent of the President, fixing monetary limits for
filing appeal, application, revision or reference shall be deemed to have been
issued under sub-section (1), and the provisions of sub-sections (2), (3) 
and (4) shall apply  accordingly.]

 Section 131C

Data from Section 131C:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <p>
   <b>
    Section 131C.  Definitions.-
    <br>
   </b>
  </p>
  <p>
   In this Chapter -
  </p>
  <p>
   (a) "appointed day" means the date of coming into force of the
amendments to this Act specified in Part I of the Fifth Schedule to the Finance
(No. 2) Act, 1980 (44 of 1980) ;
  </p>
  <p>
   (b)  "High Court" means,-
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (i) in relation to any State, the High Court for that State;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (ii) in relation to a Union territory to which the jurisdiction of the High
Court of a State has been extended by law, that High Court;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (iii) in relation to the Union territories of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and
   <sup>
    1
   </sup>
   [Daman
and Diu], the High Court at Bombay;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (iv) in relation to any other Union territory, the highest court of civil
appeal for that territory other than the Supreme Court of India;
  </p>
  (c)   "President" means the President of the Appellate
Tribunal.
  <br>
  <br>
  <div class="footnotes">
   <br>
   <br>
   1. Substituted (w.e.f. 30-5-1987) by s. 5 of Goa, Daman and Diu Reorganisation Act, 1987 (18 of 1987).
   <br>
  </div>
 
</span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153="">
 
 
 
  <p>
   <b>

    <br>
   </b>
  </p>
  <p>

  </p>
  <p>
   (a) "appointed day" means the date of coming into force of the
amendments to this Act specified in Part I of the Fifth Schedule to the Finance
(No. 2) Act, 1980 (44 of 1980) ;
  </p>
  <p>
   (b)  "High Court" means,-
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (i) in relation to any State, the High Court for that State;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (ii) in relation to a Union territory to which the jurisdiction of the High
Court of a State has been extended by law, that High Court;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (iii) in relation to the Union territories of Dadra and Nagar Haveli and
   <sup>
    1
   </sup>
   [Daman
and Diu], the High Court at Bombay;
  </p>
  <p style="padding-left: 40px;">
   (iv) in relation to any other Union territory, the highest court of civil

  </p>

 Section 132

Data from Section 132:
Component 1:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><div id="content"><p><strong>     <span>      Section 132     </span></strong><span>     .    </span><strong>     <span>      False declaration, false documents, etc.     </span></strong><span>     -    </span></p><p>    Whoever makes, signs or uses, or causes to be made, signed or used, any declaration, statement or document in the transaction of any business relating to the customs, knowing or having reason to believe that such declaration, statement or document is false in any material particular, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to    <sup>     1    </sup>    [two years],or with fine, or with both.   </p><div class="footnotes"><p>     1. Substituted by the Taxation Laws (Amendment) Act, 2006 (29 of 2006), sec. 30, for "six months" (w.e.f. 13.07.2006).    </p></div></div></span>



Component 2:
<span _ngcontent-uwh-c153=""><div id="content"><p><strong>     <span>      Section 132     </span></strong><span>     .    </span><strong>     <span>      False declaration, false documents, etc.     </span></strong><span>     -    </span></p><p>    Whoever makes, signs or uses, or causes to be made, signed or used, any declaration, statement or document in the transaction of any business relating to the customs, knowing or having reason to believe that such declaration, statement or document is false in any material particular, shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to    <sup>     1    </sup>    [two years],or with fine, or with both.   </p><div class="footnotes"><p>     1. Substituted by the Taxation Laws (Amendment) Act, 2006 (29 of 2006), sec. 30, for "six months" (w.e.f. 13.07.2006).    </p></div></div></span>



 Section 133
